item.title: Docs: .get_keys()
item.description:
Description

The .get_keys() method provides the data array populated with the output properties earmarked as keys for the current result row.

You typically call this method in combination with a loop mechanism such as a while loop, see Example.

Signature

.get_keys()

Return type

Class py4j.java_collections.JavaArray : instance

Example

from planit import *

#prep
plan_it = PLANit()
plan_it.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC)
plan_it.assignment.set(PhysicalCost.BPR)
plan_it.assignment.set(VirtualCost.FIXED)
plan_it.assignment.set(Smoothing.MSA)

# remove default formatter - activate memory output
plan_it.deactivate(OutputFormatter.PLANIT_IO)
plan_it.activate(OutputFormatter.MEMORY)

# run simulation
plan_it.run()

#collect iteration index of last recorded iteration
i = plan_it.memory.get_last_iteration()

# find position of flow result for mode 1, time period 2, iteration i
flow_pos = plan_it.memory.get_position_of_output_value_property(1, 2, i, OutputType.LINK, OutputProperty.FLOW)

# find position of key; we use link segment (external) id	
id_pos = plan_it.memory.get_position_of_output_key_property(1, 2, i, OutputType.LINK, OutputProperty.LINK_SEGMENT_EXTERNAL_ID)

# collect iterator and print results by looping over entries
link_iter = plan_it.memory.iterator(1, 2, i, OutputType.LINK)
while link_iter.has_next():
	link_iter.next()
	print "id: ", link_iter.get_keys()[id_pos], " flow: ", link_iter.get_values()[flow_pos]

See also

N/A

Source code

Class MemoryOutputIteratorWrapper in Wrappers.py

item.title: Docs: .get_values()
item.description:
Description

The .get_values() method provides the data array populated with the output properties earmarked as result values for the current result row.

You typically call this method in combination with a loop mechanism such as a while loop, see Example.

Signature

.get_values()

Return type

Class py4j.java_collections.JavaArray : instance

Example

from planit import *

#prep
plan_it = PLANit()
plan_it.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC)
plan_it.assignment.set(PhysicalCost.BPR)
plan_it.assignment.set(VirtualCost.FIXED)
plan_it.assignment.set(Smoothing.MSA)

# remove default formatter - activate memory output
plan_it.deactivate(OutputFormatter.PLANIT_IO)
plan_it.activate(OutputFormatter.MEMORY)

# run simulation
plan_it.run()

#collect iteration index of last recorded iteration
i = plan_it.memory.get_last_iteration()

# find position of flow result for mode 1, time period 2, iteration i
flow_pos = plan_it.memory.get_position_of_output_value_property(1, 2, i, OutputType.LINK, OutputProperty.FLOW)

# find position of key; we use link segment (external) id	
id_pos = plan_it.memory.get_position_of_output_key_property(1, 2, i, OutputType.LINK, OutputProperty.LINK_SEGMENT_EXTERNAL_ID)

# collect iterator and print results by looping over entries
link_iter = plan_it.memory.iterator(1, 2, i, OutputType.LINK)
while link_iter.has_next():
	link_iter.next()
	print "id: ", link_iter.get_keys()[id_pos], " flow: ", link_iter.get_values()[flow_pos]

See also

N/A

Source code

item.title: Docs: .has_next()
item.description:
Description

The .has_next() method allows you to verify if the iterator has traversed all result rows or not.

You typically call this method in combination with a loop mechanism such as a while loop, see Example.

Signature

.has_next()

Return type

boolean : true when there are more result rows, false otherwise

Example

from planit import *

#prep
plan_it = PLANit()
plan_it.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC)
plan_it.assignment.set(PhysicalCost.BPR)
plan_it.assignment.set(VirtualCost.FIXED)
plan_it.assignment.set(Smoothing.MSA)

# remove default formatter - activate memory output
plan_it.deactivate(OutputFormatter.PLANIT_IO)
plan_it.activate(OutputFormatter.MEMORY)

# run simulation
plan_it.run()

#collect iteration index of last recorded iteration
i = plan_it.memory.get_last_iteration()

# find position of flow result for mode 1, time period 2, iteration i
flow_pos = plan_it.memory.get_position_of_output_value_property(1, 2, i, OutputType.LINK, OutputProperty.FLOW)

# find position of key; we use link segment (external) id	
id_pos = plan_it.memory.get_position_of_output_key_property(1, 2, i, OutputType.LINK, OutputProperty.LINK_SEGMENT_EXTERNAL_ID)

# collect iterator and print results by looping over entries
link_iter = plan_it.memory.iterator(1, 2, i, OutputType.LINK)
while link_iter.has_next():
	link_iter.next()
	print "id: ", link_iter.get_keys()[id_pos], " flow: ", link_iter.get_values()[flow_pos]

See also

N/A

Source code

item.title: Docs: .next()
item.description:
Description

The .next() method moves the iterator’s position to the next result row (if available).

You typically call this method in combination with a loop mechanism such as a while loop, see Example.

Signature

.next()

Return type

None

Example

from planit import *

#prep
plan_it = PLANit()
plan_it.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC)
plan_it.assignment.set(PhysicalCost.BPR)
plan_it.assignment.set(VirtualCost.FIXED)
plan_it.assignment.set(Smoothing.MSA)

# remove default formatter - activate memory output
plan_it.deactivate(OutputFormatter.PLANIT_IO)
plan_it.activate(OutputFormatter.MEMORY)

# run simulation
plan_it.run()

#collect iteration index of last recorded iteration
i = plan_it.memory.get_last_iteration()

# find position of flow result for mode 1, time period 2, iteration i
flow_pos = plan_it.memory.get_position_of_output_value_property(1, 2, i, OutputType.LINK, OutputProperty.FLOW)

# find position of key; we use link segment (external) id	
id_pos = plan_it.memory.get_position_of_output_key_property(1, 2, i, OutputType.LINK, OutputProperty.LINK_SEGMENT_EXTERNAL_ID)

# collect iterator and print results by looping over entries
link_iter = plan_it.memory.iterator(1, 2, i, OutputType.LINK)
while link_iter.has_next():
	link_iter.next()
	print "id: ", link_iter.get_keys()[id_pos], " flow: ", link_iter.get_values()[flow_pos]

See also

N/A
